questions.question: A security interest attaches to collateral when all of the following occur EXCEPT:

options.A: Value is given by the secured party
options.B: The debtor has rights in the collateral
options.C: A security agreement is authenticated or secured party has possession
options.D: The security interest is filed with the Secretary of State

questions.explanation: Attachment requires: (1) value given by secured party, (2) debtor has rights in collateral, and (3) authenticated security agreement describing collateral OR secured party possession. Filing is required for perfection, not attachment. Attachment gives the secured party rights against the debtor.
questions.tip: Attachment = rights against debtor (VAR: Value, Agreement, Rights). Perfection = rights against third parties (filing).

questions.question: A UCC-1 financing statement is filed to:

options.A: Create the security interest
options.B: Perfect the security interest
options.C: Foreclose on collateral
options.D: Release the debtor from liability

questions.explanation: Filing a financing statement (UCC-1) is the most common method of perfecting a security interest. Perfection establishes priority against other creditors and protects against the debtor's bankruptcy. The UCC-1 must contain the debtor's name, secured party's name, and collateral description.
questions.tip: Filing perfects the interest, doesn't create it. Attachment creates; perfection protects against third parties.

questions.question: A surety differs from a guarantor primarily in that a surety:

options.A: Has no liability until the principal debtor defaults
options.B: Is primarily liable along with the principal debtor
options.C: Must be compensated for the promise
options.D: Cannot assert defenses of the principal debtor

questions.explanation: A surety is primarily liable—the creditor can seek payment from either the principal debtor or surety from the start. A guarantor of collection is secondarily liable—the creditor must first exhaust remedies against the principal debtor. A guarantor of payment is essentially a surety.
questions.tip: Surety = primarily liable (can be sued immediately). Guarantor of collection = secondarily liable (creditor must sue debtor first).

questions.question: A security interest in which type of collateral can be perfected ONLY by possession?

options.A: Inventory
options.B: Equipment
options.C: Money
options.D: Accounts receivable

questions.explanation: Money can only be perfected by possession or control—filing is not effective for money. Other collateral types (inventory, equipment, accounts) can be perfected by filing. Instruments and negotiable documents can be perfected by filing or possession, but possession provides better protection.
questions.tip: Money = possession only. Accounts/general intangibles = filing only. Most others = filing or possession.

questions.question: A standard UCC-1 financing statement is effective for:

options.A: 1 year
options.B: 3 years
options.C: 5 years
options.D: Indefinitely

questions.explanation: A standard financing statement is effective for 5 years from filing. A continuation statement must be filed within 6 months before expiration to continue effectiveness for another 5 years. If no continuation is filed, the financing statement lapses and the security interest becomes unperfected.
questions.tip: UCC-1 = 5 years. Continuation must be filed 6 months before expiration. Lapse = unperfected.

questions.question: After paying the creditor, a surety has the right of:

options.A: Marshaling only
options.B: Subrogation to the creditor's rights against the debtor
options.C: Revocation of the surety agreement
options.D: Additional compensation from the creditor

questions.explanation: After paying the creditor, a surety has the right of subrogation—stepping into the creditor's shoes to pursue the principal debtor for reimbursement. The surety also has rights of reimbursement (direct right against debtor) and contribution (from co-sureties).
questions.tip: Surety rights after payment: Subrogation, Reimbursement, Contribution (from co-sureties).

questions.question: A purchase money security interest (PMSI) arises when:

options.A: The collateral is purchased at a foreclosure sale
options.B: The secured party provides value to enable the debtor to acquire the collateral
options.C: The debtor pledges real property as security
options.D: Multiple creditors share the same collateral

questions.explanation: A PMSI exists when the secured party's value enables the debtor to acquire the collateral (seller credit or enabling loan). PMSIs get special priority rules—they can take priority over earlier-filed security interests if properly perfected within the grace period.
questions.tip: PMSI: seller finances purchase OR lender enables purchase. Special priority if perfected within 20 days (goods).

questions.question: Between two perfected secured creditors, priority generally goes to:

options.A: The creditor with the larger claim
options.B: The creditor who filed or perfected first
options.C: The creditor who lent the most money
options.D: The creditor whose agreement was signed first

questions.explanation: Under the first-to-file-or-perfect rule, priority between competing perfected security interests goes to the one who filed or perfected first, whichever is earlier. An unperfected security interest loses to a perfected one. Between unperfected interests, first to attach wins.
questions.tip: First to file or perfect wins. Filing can occur before attachment, creating priority from filing date.

questions.question: Which of the following releases a surety from liability?

options.A: Bankruptcy of the principal debtor
options.B: Material modification of the debtor's obligation without surety consent
options.C: The debtor's failure to give notice of default
options.D: Assignment of the debt to a new creditor

questions.explanation: A compensated surety is discharged to the extent of harm caused by a material modification (change in terms, extension of time, release of collateral) made without consent. The debtor's bankruptcy, late notice, or assignment generally do not discharge the surety.
questions.tip: Material changes without consent discharge surety (to extent harmed). Compensated surety = only discharged to extent of harm.

questions.question: An after-acquired property clause in a security agreement:

options.A: Is generally unenforceable
options.B: Automatically covers property the debtor later acquires
options.C: Requires a new security agreement for each acquisition
options.D: Only applies to real property

questions.explanation: An after-acquired property clause in a security agreement makes the security interest attach to property the debtor acquires after the agreement is executed. The security interest attaches automatically when the debtor acquires rights in the new collateral. This is common for inventory and accounts financing.
questions.tip: After-acquired clause: one filing covers future property. Interest attaches when debtor acquires rights.

questions.question: A buyer in the ordinary course of business takes goods:

options.A: Subject to all prior security interests
options.B: Free of a security interest created by the seller
options.C: Only if the buyer conducts a UCC search
options.D: Free of all liens and encumbrances

questions.explanation: A buyer in the ordinary course (BIOC) takes goods free of a security interest created by the seller, even if the buyer knows of its existence. This protects consumers and businesses buying inventory from merchants. The buyer must buy from a seller in the business of selling goods of that kind.
questions.tip: BIOC defeats security interest created by seller (inventory). Does NOT defeat security interest created by someone else.

questions.question: When co-sureties agree to be liable for a $300,000 debt with maximum exposures of $100,000, $150,000, and $150,000, and one surety pays $200,000, that surety can seek contribution from the others based on:

options.A: Equal shares regardless of maximum exposure
options.B: Pro rata based on their maximum liability
options.C: No contribution is allowed among co-sureties
options.D: First-in-time priority

questions.explanation: Co-sureties share liability pro rata based on their maximum exposure. Here the ratios are $100K:$150K:$150K or 1:1.5:1.5. The paying surety can seek contribution from co-sureties for amounts exceeding their pro rata share. Total maximum is $400K, so ratios are 25%, 37.5%, 37.5%.
questions.tip: Contribution: pro rata by maximum exposure. Calculate each surety's share of actual loss based on their portion of total.

questions.question: A security interest in collateral automatically continues in:

options.A: Any property the debtor purchases
options.B: Identifiable proceeds from the collateral
options.C: The debtor's personal assets
options.D: Property sold to the debtor by third parties

questions.explanation: A security interest automatically continues in identifiable proceeds—whatever is received when collateral is sold, exchanged, or disposed of. This includes cash, accounts receivable, or new goods received in exchange. Perfection continues in proceeds for 20 days and may continue indefinitely if certain conditions are met.
questions.tip: Proceeds: automatically covered. Perfection continues 20 days, longer if same filing office or cash proceeds.

questions.question: For most types of collateral, a UCC financing statement should be filed:

options.A: In the county where the collateral is located
options.B: In the state where the debtor is located
options.C: In the state where the secured party is located
options.D: In every state where the debtor does business

questions.explanation: For most collateral, the proper filing location is the state where the debtor is located. For registered organizations (corporations, LLCs), this is the state of organization. For individuals, it's their principal residence. Filing in the wrong state fails to perfect the security interest.
questions.tip: File where debtor is located. Corporation = state of incorporation. Individual = principal residence. Fixtures = real property records.

questions.question: A promise to answer for another's debt (suretyship) is:

options.A: Enforceable without any writing
options.B: Required to be in writing under the Statute of Frauds
options.C: Only valid if notarized
options.D: Unenforceable regardless of formalities

questions.explanation: Under the Statute of Frauds, a promise to answer for the debt of another must be in writing and signed by the party to be charged. The main purpose exception applies: if the surety's main purpose is their own benefit, no writing is required.
questions.tip: Suretyship = writing required. Main purpose exception: if surety benefits primarily, no writing needed.

questions.question: Upon default, a secured party may do all of the following EXCEPT:

options.A: Take possession of collateral without judicial process if done peacefully
options.B: Sell the collateral at a public or private sale
options.C: Retain the collateral in full satisfaction without notice
options.D: Apply proceeds to the debt after covering expenses

questions.explanation: The secured party may repossess (peacefully or judicially), sell (with notice), or retain in full satisfaction (strict foreclosure). However, strict foreclosure requires notice and the debtor can object within 20 days for consumer goods or 60% paid situations. Proceeds are applied: expenses, debt, junior liens, then surplus to debtor.
questions.tip: Strict foreclosure: must send proposal and notice. Consumer goods = debtor can object. 60% paid = must sell.

questions.question: To have priority, a PMSI in inventory must be perfected:

options.A: Within 20 days after debtor receives possession
options.B: Before the debtor receives possession of the inventory
options.C: Within 10 days after delivery
options.D: Any time before default

questions.explanation: A PMSI in inventory must be perfected before the debtor receives possession AND the PMSI creditor must notify prior secured parties. This is stricter than non-inventory PMSI (20-day grace period). The notification requirement prevents prior creditors from unknowingly advancing against encumbered inventory.
questions.tip: PMSI inventory: perfect BEFORE delivery + notify prior creditors. PMSI non-inventory: 20-day grace period, no notice.

questions.question: A surety's right of exoneration allows the surety to:

options.A: Be released from liability at any time
options.B: Compel the principal debtor to pay the debt when due
options.C: Collect from co-sureties before paying
options.D: Require the creditor to proceed against collateral first

questions.explanation: Exoneration is the surety's right to compel the principal debtor to pay the obligation when due, before the surety must pay. This prevents the debtor from waiting for the surety to pay and then claiming inability to reimburse. Marshaling requires the creditor to pursue the debtor's assets first.
questions.tip: Exoneration: force debtor to pay. Marshaling: force creditor to pursue debtor's property first.

questions.question: A PMSI in consumer goods is perfected:

options.A: Only by filing a financing statement
options.B: Automatically upon attachment without filing
options.C: By taking possession of the goods
options.D: By notifying other creditors

questions.explanation: A PMSI in consumer goods is automatically perfected upon attachment—no filing is required. However, filing is still advisable to protect against buyers who don't know of the security interest. Without filing, a buyer for personal use without knowledge takes free of the interest.
questions.tip: Consumer goods PMSI = automatic perfection. But file anyway to protect against innocent buyers.

questions.question: A security agreement's description of collateral must:

options.A: Include serial numbers for all goods
options.B: Reasonably identify the collateral
options.C: List every item separately
options.D: Be notarized

questions.explanation: The security agreement must reasonably identify the collateral. This can be by specific listing, category, type, or any other method that identifies it. A supergeneric description ('all assets') is sufficient in a financing statement but not in the security agreement itself.
questions.tip: Security agreement: reasonably identify. Financing statement: supergeneric OK. 'All assets' = filing OK, security agreement NOT OK.

questions.question: A security interest in fixtures should be filed:

options.A: Only with the Secretary of State
options.B: In the real property records where the real property is located
options.C: Only by taking possession
options.D: With the county assessor

questions.explanation: A fixture filing is made in the office where a mortgage on the related real property would be recorded (real property records). The filing must describe the real property and indicate that it covers fixtures. This protects the secured party against real property claimants.
questions.tip: Fixtures: file in real property records (where mortgage would be filed). Different from regular UCC filing location.

questions.question: If a creditor releases the principal debtor from liability:

options.A: The surety is automatically released
options.B: The surety remains fully liable unless the release expressly reserves rights against the surety
options.C: The surety is released only if the release was for valuable consideration
options.D: The surety is released to the extent of the principal's ability to pay

questions.explanation: Under the Restatement approach, if the creditor releases the principal debtor, the surety is generally released unless the creditor expressly reserves rights against the surety. If rights are reserved, the surety remains liable but retains all rights against the principal debtor.
questions.tip: Release of debtor without reservation = surety released. With reservation of rights = surety still liable.

questions.question: A future advance clause in a security agreement:

options.A: Requires a new filing for each advance
options.B: Allows the original security interest to secure later loans
options.C: Is unenforceable under the UCC
options.D: Only covers advances made within 30 days

questions.explanation: A future advance clause allows the security interest to secure not only the original loan but also future advances made by the secured party. Priority for future advances generally relates back to the original filing date. This is common in revolving credit and line of credit arrangements.
questions.tip: Future advance clause: one filing, multiple loans. Priority dates from original filing (for most advances).

questions.question: An unperfected security interest is subordinate to:

options.A: Other unperfected security interests
options.B: A person who becomes a lien creditor before perfection
options.C: The debtor in all circumstances
options.D: No other parties

questions.explanation: An unperfected security interest loses to a lien creditor who becomes such before the security interest is perfected. A lien creditor includes a judgment creditor, assignee for benefit of creditors, and bankruptcy trustee. This makes perfection critical for protection in bankruptcy.
questions.tip: Unperfected loses to lien creditors. Bankruptcy trustee = lien creditor as of filing. Perfect promptly!

questions.question: If a creditor releases collateral securing the principal debtor's obligation, a compensated surety is:

options.A: Fully discharged
options.B: Discharged to the extent the surety is harmed by the release
options.C: Not affected
options.D: Liable for double the original amount

questions.explanation: Under the modern view, a compensated surety is discharged only to the extent actually harmed by the creditor's impairment of collateral. This is measured by the value of the collateral released. An uncompensated (gratuitous) surety may be completely discharged by any impairment.
questions.tip: Compensated surety: discharged to extent of harm. Gratuitous surety: may be fully discharged by impairment.

questions.question: If a debtor changes its name and the financing statement becomes seriously misleading, the secured party:

options.A: Must refile within 30 days or lose priority
options.B: Has 4 months to file an amendment or loses perfection in after-acquired collateral
options.C: Is automatically terminated
options.D: Retains perfection indefinitely without any action

questions.explanation: If a debtor name change makes the financing statement seriously misleading, the secured party has 4 months to file an amendment. If not filed, perfection is lost for collateral acquired more than 4 months after the change. Collateral acquired before or within 4 months remains perfected.
questions.tip: Name change: 4-month window to amend. After 4 months, lose perfection in after-acquired collateral only.

questions.question: A security interest in accessions (goods installed in or affixed to other goods):

options.A: Is automatically terminated when goods are installed
options.B: Continues in the accession after installation
options.C: Must be refiled after the goods are combined
options.D: Is subordinate to all other interests in the whole

questions.explanation: A security interest in accessions continues after the goods are installed in or affixed to other goods. The secured party has priority in the accession over claimants to the whole if the security interest in the accession is perfected. However, the secured party generally cannot remove accessions if it would cause damage.
questions.tip: Accession security interest continues after installation. Priority based on when accession interest was perfected.

questions.question: If a creditor releases one co-surety, the remaining co-sureties are:

options.A: Fully liable for the entire debt
options.B: Released to the extent of the released surety's share
options.C: Entitled to indemnification from the creditor
options.D: Automatically released

questions.explanation: When a creditor releases one co-surety, the remaining co-sureties are generally discharged to the extent they would have been entitled to contribution from the released surety. This prevents the creditor from shifting a disproportionate burden to the remaining sureties.
questions.tip: Release of one co-surety: others discharged to extent of released surety's share. Protects contribution rights.

questions.question: A security interest in a deposit account can be perfected by:

options.A: Filing a financing statement
options.B: Control only
options.C: Possession or filing
options.D: Attachment alone

questions.explanation: A security interest in a deposit account (as original collateral) can only be perfected by control. The secured party has control if it is the bank, the debtor authorizes the bank to follow instructions without debtor consent, or the secured party becomes the bank's customer. Filing is not effective.
questions.tip: Deposit accounts: control only. Investment property: control OR filing (control beats filing). Letter of credit rights: control.

questions.question: A subordination agreement between secured creditors:

options.A: Is unenforceable under the UCC
options.B: Allows parties to contractually change their priority positions
options.C: Requires approval by the debtor
options.D: Must be filed to be effective

questions.explanation: The UCC expressly provides that secured parties may agree to subordinate their priority. A subordination agreement is enforceable between the parties without filing or debtor consent. This is commonly used when senior lenders agree to let new financing take priority.
questions.tip: Subordination agreements: enforceable between parties. No filing needed. Common in intercreditor agreements.

questions.question: If the principal debtor induces the surety to sign through fraud unknown to the creditor:

options.A: The surety can avoid liability to the creditor
options.B: The surety remains liable to the creditor but has recourse against the debtor
options.C: The creditor must refund any payments received
options.D: The suretyship is void from inception

questions.explanation: Fraud by the principal debtor that is unknown to the creditor does not release the surety from liability to the creditor. The surety's remedy is against the principal debtor who committed the fraud. If the creditor participated in or knew of the fraud, the surety may be released.
questions.tip: Debtor's fraud (unknown to creditor): surety still liable, can sue debtor. Creditor's fraud: surety released.

questions.question: When goods subject to a security interest are manufactured into or commingled with other goods:

options.A: The security interest is extinguished
options.B: The security interest continues in the product or mass
options.C: The secured party must trace the specific goods
options.D: The debtor's liability is discharged

questions.explanation: When collateral is manufactured into a product or commingled with other goods so that identity is lost, the security interest continues in the product or mass. If more than one security interest attaches to the product/mass, they rank equally and share pro rata by their pre-commingling values.
questions.tip: Commingled goods: security interest continues in mass. Multiple interests share pro rata by original value.

questions.question: An agricultural lien differs from a security interest in that it:

options.A: Cannot be perfected by filing
options.B: Arises by statute rather than agreement
options.C: Has no priority against other creditors
options.D: Only covers real property

questions.explanation: An agricultural lien is a nonpossessory lien on farm products that arises by statute to secure payment for goods, services, or rent furnished in connection with a debtor's farming operation. Unlike security interests, agricultural liens don't require a security agreement—they're created by operation of law.
questions.tip: Agricultural liens: statutory creation, not contractual. Still must file to perfect. Priority determined by UCC rules.

questions.question: If the principal debtor tenders full payment to the creditor but the creditor refuses it:

options.A: The surety remains fully liable
options.B: The surety is discharged
options.C: The creditor can still pursue the surety
options.D: The surety must pay and seek subrogation

questions.explanation: If the principal debtor makes a valid tender of payment and the creditor refuses it, the surety is discharged. This is because the surety should not be held liable when the debtor has offered to perform but the creditor wrongfully rejected the tender.
questions.tip: Creditor refuses valid tender from debtor = surety discharged. Creditor's wrongful refusal releases surety.

questions.question: After foreclosure sale, if the sale proceeds are insufficient to satisfy the debt, the secured party:

options.A: Cannot pursue the debtor for any deficiency
options.B: May obtain a deficiency judgment for the balance in most cases
options.C: Must conduct a second sale
options.D: Must return the collateral to the debtor

questions.explanation: If the foreclosure sale proceeds are insufficient to pay the debt, the secured party may generally obtain a deficiency judgment against the debtor for the remaining balance. However, if the sale was not conducted in a commercially reasonable manner, the deficiency may be limited or barred.
questions.tip: Deficiency judgment generally allowed. Commercially unreasonable sale may bar deficiency. Consumer goods = special protections.
